    Highlights

    •
    The genome and responses of a charophyte alga uncover terrestrialization mechanisms
    •
    Paradoxical presence of protective UV-absorbing flavonoid pigments
    •
    Evolutionary origins of plant hydrophobic polymer classes that limit water loss
    •
    Expanded repertoire of genes for polysaccharide cell wall biosynthesis and remodeling

    Summary

    The evolutionary features and molecular innovations that enabled plants to first colonize land are not well understood. Here, insights are provided through our report of the genome sequence of the unicellular alga Penium margaritaceum, a member of the Zygnematophyceae, the sister lineage to land plants. The genome has a high proportion of repeat sequences that are associated with massive segmental gene duplications, likely facilitating neofunctionalization. Compared with representatives of earlier diverging algal lineages, P. margaritaceum has expanded repertoires of gene families, signaling networks, and adaptive responses that highlight the evolutionary trajectory toward terrestrialization. These encompass a broad range of physiological processes and protective cellular features, such as flavonoid compounds and large families of modifying enzymes involved in cell wall biosynthesis, assembly, and remodeling. Transcriptome profiling further elucidated adaptations, responses, and selective pressures associated with the semi-terrestrial ecosystems of P. margaritaceum, where a simple body plan would be an advantage.

    Graphical Abstract

    Keywords

    1. Zygnematophyceae
    2. Penium
    3. unicellular algae
    4. plant evolution
    5. terrestrial abiotic stresses
    6. phytohormone
    7. cell wall
    8. flavonoids
    9. transcriptional regulation
    10. gene family evolution

    Introduction

    One of the most momentous evolutionary events in the history of life on Earth is thought to have occurred approximately 600 million years ago (mya) (Morris et al., 2018
    90.
    Morris, J.L. ∙ Puttick, M.N. ∙ Clark, J.W. ...
    The timescale of early land plant evolution
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2018; 115:E2274-E2283
    Crossref
    Scopus (195)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), when a single lineage of freshwater algae developed the capacity to colonize land (Delwiche and Timme, 2011
    34.
    Delwiche, C.F. ∙ Timme, R.E.
    Plants
    Curr. Biol. 2011; 21:R417-R422
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). These pioneering oxygenating autotrophs had a profound effect on the atmosphere and geochemical composition of the soil (Delwiche and Cooper, 2015; Rensing, 2018
    33.
    Delwiche, C.F. ∙ Cooper, E.D.
    The evolutionary origin of a terrestrial flora
    Curr. Biol. 2015; 25:R899-R910
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    113.
    Rensing, S.A.
    Great moments in evolution: the conquest of land by plants
    Curr. Opin. Plant Biol. 2018; 42:49-54
    Crossref
    Scopus (46)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and paved the way for an explosion of land plant diversification. Green plants (Viridiplantae) are comprised of the chlorophyte algae and the monophyletic group Streptophyta, which consists of land plants (embryophytes) and charophyte algae (Figure 1A). There is now considerable molecular evidence that the late divergent charophyte group Zygnematophyceae includes the closest relatives of land plants (Cheng et al., 2019; Leebens-Mack et al., 2019
    21.
    Cheng, S. ∙ Xian, W. ∙ Fu, Y. ...
    Genomes of subaerial Zygnematophyceae provide insights into land plant evolution
    Cell. 2019; 179:1057-1067.e14
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (58)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    69.
    Leebens-Mack, J.H. ∙ Barker, M.S. ∙ Carpenter, E.J. ..., One Thousand Plant Transcriptomes Initiative
    One thousand plant transcriptomes and the phylogenomics of green plants
    Nature. 2019; 574:679-685
    Crossref
    Scopus (168)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). However, this might be considered somewhat counterintuitive as members of the Zygnematophyceae exhibit a notably simpler body plan (e.g., unicells and filaments) than the multicellular, branched members of the Charophyceae or Coleochaetophyceae and also undergo sexual reproduction via conjugation rather than oogamy.
    Extant charophytes have a remarkable range of body plans, even though fossil evidence suggests that they represent only a small proportion of the variation that existed previously (Feist et al., 2005
    44.
    Feist, M. ∙ Liu, J. ∙ Tafforeau, P.
    New insights into Paleozoic charophyte morphology and phylogeny
    Am. J. Bot. 2005; 92:1152-1160
    Crossref
    Scopus (46)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). This morphological diversity and its underlying developmental machinery provide a rich set of opportunities to elucidate adaptations that might have been critical for the invasion of land. Here we present the genome and transcriptomes of the unicellular desmid Penium margaritaceum, an archetype of the Zygnematophyceae with the simplest of body plans (Figure 1B). P. margaritaceum has an architecturally complex land plant-like cell wall (Domozych et al., 2007; 2014; Sørensen et al., 2011
    38.
    Domozych, D.S. ∙ Serfis, A. ∙ Kiemle, S.N. ...
    The structure and biochemistry of charophycean cell walls: I. Pectins of Penium margaritaceum
    Protoplasma. 2007; 230:99-115
    Crossref
    Scopus (65)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    39.
    Domozych, D.S. ∙ Sørensen, I. ∙ Popper, Z.A. ...
    Pectin metabolism and assembly in the cell wall of the charophyte green alga Penium margaritaceum
    Plant Physiol. 2014; 165:105-118
    Crossref
    Scopus (52)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    122.
    Sørensen, I. ∙ Pettolino, F.A. ∙ Bacic, A. ...
    The charophycean green algae provide insights into the early origins of plant cell walls
    Plant J. 2011; 68:201-211
    Crossref
    Scopus (137)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and secretes mucilaginous polysaccharides (Figures 1C and 1D), which might be associated with its adaptation to living in transient wetlands that experience frequent drying. In this study, we sought to identify suites of genes and processes that facilitate adaptation to an ephemeral semi-terrestrial life style and determine whether the relatively simple morphology of P. margaritaceum is associated with genome features, such as reductionism, compared with that of other charophyte lineages that have more complex multicellular body plans. We further investigated the responses of P. margaritaceum to a range of abiotic stresses to elucidate the adaptations that enable tolerance of the environmental challenges imposed by terrestrial habitats.

    Results

    Genome and Gene Set of P. margaritaceum

    We generated a total of 954 Gb Illumina paired-end and 433 Gb mate-pair sequences (Table S1A) representing 201× and 92× coverage, respectively, of the haploid genome of P. margaritaceum with an estimated size of 4.7 Gb (Data S1A). Assembly of these sequences resulted in 332,786 scaffolds with a cumulative size of 3.661 Gb and an N50 of 116.1 kb. The assembly captured most of the k-mers in the Illumina reads, and low-frequency k-mers representing sequencing errors were absent (Data S1A). In addition, the mapping rates of genomic and RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) reads against the assembly were 97.5% and 96.8%, respectively (Table S1B). The single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) frequency distribution on the 100 longest scaffolds was consistent with a haploid genome (Data S1A). The mitochondrial and chloroplast genomes were also fully assembled and comprised 95,332 and 145,411 nucleotides, respectively (Data S1B).
    The assembly contains a large proportion (80.6%) of repeat sequences (Table S1C), particularly long terminal repeat (LTR) retrotransposons and simple repeats (Figure 2A). Unlike land plants and most other green algae, in which gypsy is the predominant LTR retrotransposon family, the P. margaritaceum genome has a large proportion of copia retrotransposons, which are rare in other late-divergent charophytes and absent from Chara braunii (Nishiyama et al., 2018
    97.
    Nishiyama, T. ∙ Sakayama, H. ∙ de Vries, J. ...
    The Chara genome: secondary complexity and implications for plant terrestrialization
    Cell. 2018; 174:448-464.e24
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (122)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). An estimation of divergence time indicated that the copia expansion in the P. margaritaceum genome was relatively recent, around 2.1 mya (Figure 2B). Retrotransposons carrying tyrosine recombinases, such as the Dictyostelium intermediate repeat sequence (DIRS) and Ngaro families, which are found in some chlorophyte and charophyte genomes, are not present in the zygnematophycean algae P. margaritaceum and Spirogloea muscicola or in land plants (Figure 2A). However, DIRS retrotransposons are found in another zygnematophycean alga, Mesotaenium endlicherianum, suggesting separate secondary losses in some of the Zygnematophyceae and the embryophyte lineage.
    We predicted 52,333 high-confidence protein-coding genes in the P. margaritaceum genome, of which 99.3% were supported by RNA-seq data or by homologs in the NCBI non-redundant protein database. An assessment of gene space completeness using BUSCO (Simão et al., 2015
    121.
    Simão, F.A. ∙ Waterhouse, R.M. ∙ Ioannidis, P. ...
    BUSCO: assessing genome assembly and annotation completeness with single-copy orthologs
    Bioinformatics. 2015; 31:3210-3212
    Crossref
    Scopus (2893)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) indicated a low rate of missing genes (8.25%) but a relatively high fragmented gene rate (21.45%). To inform the annotation, we performed transcriptome sequencing with Pacific Biosciences (PacBio) long-read isoform sequencing (Iso-Seq) technology, which generated 52,134 full-length transcripts consisting of 73,813 isoforms. These PacBio transcripts, together with 145,267 representative transcripts assembled from RNA-seq data, were used to build a master gene set by integration with the high-confidence gene models. The final master gene set consisted of 53,262 genes. The missing and fragmented gene rates of the master gene set were 2.31% and 13.20%, respectively, and the complete BUSCO rate was 84.49% (Table S1D). This master gene set was used for downstream analyses.

    Genome and Gene Family Evolution

    Orthologous genes among P. margaritaceum and 17 representative species spanning the green plant lineage were identified. Phylogenetic analysis of low-copy orthologous groups confirmed the close relationship between Zygnematophyceae and land plants and revealed divergence times deep within the Zygnematophyceae lineage. P. margaritaceum diverged from M. endlicherianum ~496 mya, predating a proposed crown origin of embryophytes (473 mya) (Figure 3A; Table S1E). The P. margaritaceum genome has not undergone any recent whole-genome duplications (WGDs) (Data S1C), which were also not evident in other sequenced charophytes except S. muscicola, whose genome experienced a recent triplication event (Cheng et al., 2019; Nishiyama et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2020
    21.
    Cheng, S. ∙ Xian, W. ∙ Fu, Y. ...
    Genomes of subaerial Zygnematophyceae provide insights into land plant evolution
    Cell. 2019; 179:1057-1067.e14
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (58)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    97.
    Nishiyama, T. ∙ Sakayama, H. ∙ de Vries, J. ...
    The Chara genome: secondary complexity and implications for plant terrestrialization
    Cell. 2018; 174:448-464.e24
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (122)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    136.
    Wang, S. ∙ Li, L. ∙ Li, H. ...
    Genomes of early-diverging streptophyte algae shed light on plant terrestrialization
    Nat. Plants. 2020; 6:95-106
    Crossref
    Scopus (28)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). However, substantial segmental gene duplications were found in P. margaritaceum, which is consistent with the high transposable element (TE) abundance, given that massive segmental gene duplications are often present in organisms with a high TE content (Panchy et al., 2016
    102.
    Panchy, N. ∙ Lehti-Shiu, M. ∙ Shiu, S.-H.
    Evolution of gene duplication in plants
    Plant Physiol. 2016; 171:2294-2316
    Crossref
    Scopus (342)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    We looked for evidence of morphological and physiological adaptations and key traits associated with terrestrialization through the reconstruction of gene family evolution, focusing on gene family expansions (Figure 3A; Table S1F). No such expansions were found (p < 0.05) between the common ancestor of the Viridiplantae and that of the streptophytes. However, bursts of gene family expansion were evident, coinciding with the emergence of various charophyte lineages. A particularly large number of expanded gene families (124, p < 0.05) was detected in the common ancestor of the Zygnematophyceae and land plants (Figure 3A). Most of these, and the gene families involved in the previous bursts, are functionally associated with responses to stresses such as water deprivation, cold, bacteria, and oxidative stress as well as production and signaling of the phytohormones abscisic acid (ABA), auxin (AUX), ethylene (ETH), and jasmonic acid (JA). Other substantially expanded gene categories are related to protein phosphorylation and cell wall organization (Table S1G).

    Transcription Factors and Transcriptional Regulators

    The P. margaritaceum genome encodes 935 transcription factors (TFs) and 454 transcriptional regulators (TRs) (Tables S1H and S1I), which are substantially more than in chlorophytes (125–221 and 136–280, respectively) or most other charophytes (97–649, 160–495). Although there appears to be a general trend between morphological complexity and the size of the TF and/or TR (TF/TR) infrastructure in land plants (Wilhelmsson et al., 2017
    139.
    Wilhelmsson, P.K.I. ∙ Mühlich, C. ∙ Ullrich, K.K. ...
    Comprehensive genome-wide classification reveals that many plant-specific transcription factors evolved in streptophyte algae
    Genome Biol. Evol. 2017; 9:3384-3397
    Crossref
    Scopus (35)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), exceptions have been reported for some chlorophyte algae (De Clerck et al., 2018; Prochnik et al., 2010
    28.
    De Clerck, O. ∙ Kao, S.-M. ∙ Bogaert, K.A. ...
    Insights into the evolution of multicellularity from the sea lettuce genome
    Curr. Biol. 2018; 28:2921-2933.e5
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (35)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    108.
    Prochnik, S.E. ∙ Umen, J. ∙ Nedelcu, A.M. ...
    Genomic analysis of organismal complexity in the multicellular green alga Volvox carteri
    Science. 2010; 329:223-226
    Crossref
    Scopus (372)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). There are similar exceptions among charophyte algae because P. margaritaceum and S. muscicola, unicellular members of the Zygnematophyceae, have considerably more TF/TRs than the multicellular, branched C. braunii (Figure S1). However, it is notable that, in some cases, the portfolio of TF/TRs is dominated by a major expansion in one or a few families, as exemplified by the large size of the trihelix TF family in C. braunii or the GRAS family in P. margaritaceum (Table S1H). Thus, secondary reductions in structural complexity, as in the unicellular P. margaritaceum, are not necessarily accompanied by reductions in total TF/TR complements, and key drivers of maintaining or expanding the regulatory infrastructure might be factors associated with adaptation to specific habitats and ecological niches. The GRAS, NAC, LOB, bZIP, basic-helix-loop-helix (bHLH), WRKY, and ERF families, all of which have been associated with abiotic stress responses in embryophytes, showed large expansions in the Zygnematophyceae, most notably in P. margaritaceum and S. muscicola, compared with those in other algal lineages (Figure 3B). Moreover, the GRAS and BBR-BPC TF families, as well as specific subfamilies of the bHLH, WRKY, NAC, and ERF families, showed evidence of having originated in the common ancestor of the Zygnematophyceae and land plants (Data S2A–S2D). For example, the P. margaritaceum genome encodes 34 proteins that are orthologs of the DREB subfamily of ERF TFs, but corresponding orthologs are not present in algae other than the Zygnematophyceae (Data S2D). In land plants, these regulatory proteins are involved in responses to abiotic stresses such as cold, dehydration, salinity, and heat (Agarwal et al., 2017
    1.
    Agarwal, P.K. ∙ Gupta, K. ∙ Lopato, S. ...
    Dehydration responsive element binding transcription factors and their applications for the engineering of stress tolerance

    Complex Polysaccharide Cell Walls

    The colonization of terrestrial habitats by embryophytes has been dependent on the ability to synthesize complex cell walls that provide biomechanical support and protection against environmental stresses. Land plant primary walls are comprised of a core scaffolding of cellulose microfibrils embedded within matrices of interconnecting pectin and hemicellulose polysaccharides together with glycoproteins (Burton et al., 2010; Dehors et al., 2019; Popper et al., 2011

CAZy enzymes are involved in diverse aspects of carbohydrate chemistry, including intracellular glycoconjugates, but notably include many that might be functionally associated with cell walls. As a general trend, the CAZy gene family sizes are smaller in chlorophytes and in the earlier-diverging charophytes Mesostigma viride and C. atmophyticus. The abundance of GH, GT, and PL genes in P. margaritaceum is particularly striking, and in the case of GTs and PLs there are more than in any of the green plant lineages. The large sizes of the classes typically reflect expansions within individual gene families (Figure 5A). Particularly prominent examples include pectinases such as the GH28 polygalacturonase and PL1 pectate lyase families and GH16 (xyloglucan transglycosylase/hydrolase [XTH] and endo-glucanase 16) enzymes, as well as the expansin family of cell wall-loosening proteins (Cosgrove, 2015

    Diversification of Extracellular Hydrophobic Polymers

    Another critical innovation for terrestrial plant life has been elaboration of specific cell wall types with other classes of structural polymers to provide additional biophysical attributes for structural support and barrier properties. Examples include the phenylpropanoid polymer lignin in xylem vessel walls and deposition of the structurally related lipid polyesters cutin and suberin, examples of which are found in the hydrophobic cuticle of epidermal cells and the endodermis of roots, respectively (Fich et al., 2016; Renault et al., 2019
    45.

    PubMed

These encode enzymes involved in intracellular biosynthesis as well as transporters and secreted proteins that have been linked to extracellular lipid trafficking and cuticle assembly (Yeats and Rose, 2013
    143.

The quantitative and qualitative changes in cuticle-associated genes from chlorophytes to land plants is marked by a transition phase from earlier- to later-diverging charophytes (Table S1M). The phylogenetic distribution of these genes is consistent with stepwise expansion and neofunctionalization of ancient core lipid biosynthetic machinery to synthesize structural lipid precursors in conjunction with systems for their secretion.     ). Development in charophytes and early land plants of mechanisms to secrete and assemble phenolic and aliphatic compounds likely gave rise to an increasingly diverse palette of protective extracellular biopolymers. Subsets of these paved the way for formation of the lignin, cutin, and suberin polymers that are found in the walls of extant land plants (Niklas et al., 2017; Philippe et al., 2020; Renault et al., 2019

    Niklas, K.J. ∙ Cobb, E.D. ∙ Matas, A.J.

    Presence of Flavonoid Compounds

    Neo- and subfunctionalization of catalytically promiscuous enzymes, including those in the ancient shikimate pathway (Niklas et al., 2017
    96.
    Niklas, K.J. ∙ Cobb, E.D. ∙ Matas, A.J.
    The evolution of hydrophobic cell wall biopolymers: from algae to angiosperms
    J. Exp. Bot. 2017; 68:5261-5269
    Crossref
    Scopus (21)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), would provide metabolic plasticity, which is associated with the evolution and functional diversification of phenylpropanoid compounds. However, the absence in the genome of P. margaritaceum and other charophytes of clear candidates for key steps in the pathway leading to various phenylpropanoid compound classes suggests the existence of cryptic activities and novel enzymes. A notable example is flavonoids, which were originally thought to only exist in land plants but have been identified in a few divergent algal lineages (Yonekura-Sakakibara et al., 2019
    144.
    Yonekura-Sakakibara, K. ∙ Higashi, Y. ∙ Nakabayashi, R.
    The origin and evolution of plant flavonoid metabolism
    Front. Plant Sci. 2019; 10:943
    Crossref
    Scopus (6)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Among other functions, flavonoids provide protection against UV radiation, which would have been a major challenge for the first land plants. We identified multiple classes of flavonoids in P. margaritaceum by mass spectrometry (Data S3A–S3D), consistent with the presence of biosynthetic routes that are commonly found in land plants (Figure S2). P. margaritaceum has homologs of 4-coumarate:coenzyme A (CoA) ligase (4CL) and, most notably, homologs of chalcone synthase (CHS), which acts at the entry to the flavonoid biosynthesis pathway. Paradoxically though, P. margaritaceum has neither PAL nor a cinnamate 4-hydroxylase (C4H) in the same cytochrome P450 subfamily (CYP73A) as the C4H genes of land plants (Yonekura-Sakakibara et al., 2019
    144.
    Yonekura-Sakakibara, K. ∙ Higashi, Y. ∙ Nakabayashi, R.
    The origin and evolution of plant flavonoid metabolism
    Front. Plant Sci. 2019; 10:943
    Crossref
    Scopus (6)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Table S1N). Thus, in P. margaritaceum, there is no clear mechanism to synthesize cinnamic acid and coumaric acid, which are intermediates in formation of the coumaroyl-CoA substrate for CHS (Figure S2). Some of the genes functioning downstream of CHS, such as chalcone isomerase (CHI) and flavanone 3-hydroxylase (F3H), which lead to the spectrum of flavonoid compounds, are also absent. There are similar absences in the genomes of the other two zygnematophycean species examined here. Whether these apparently missing steps are catalyzed by proteins in the same superfamilies as those of extant land plants but are more distantly related, or whether they represent alternative biosynthetic routes to the same products, remains an open question.

    Effects of Terrestrial Abiotic Stresses on Cellular Responses and Transcriptome Dynamics

    To gain further insights into the molecular processes and adaptations that allow P. margaritaceum to tolerate the severe physiological challenges imposed by its ephemeral habitat, we conducted transcriptome profiling of responses to two archetypal terrestrial environmental factors associated with a terrestrial habitat, desiccation (DE) and high light (HL), as well as a combination of the two (HLDE). HL had no notable effect on cellular or chloroplast morphology, but DE, and to a lesser degree HLDE, induced asymmetric cell elongation and disruption of the characteristic lobed chloroplast architecture (Figure 6A). DE and HLDE treatments also caused substantial accumulation of starch in the chloroplast as well as the formation of large cytoplasmic vacuoles, some of which showed evidence of autophagy (Data S4A). Starch degradation and biosynthesis have been observed as abiotic stress responses in different plant taxa (Thalmann and Santelia, 2017
    131.
    Thalmann, M. ∙ Santelia, D.
    Starch as a determinant of plant fitness under abiotic stress
    New Phytol. 2017; 214:943-951
    Crossref
    Scopus (79)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), and in land plants, autophagy is associated with stress tolerance, recycling of organelles and macromolecules, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) scavenging (Signorelli et al., 2019
    120.
    Signorelli, S. ∙ Tarkowski, L.P. ∙ Van den Ende, W. ...
    Linking autophagy to abiotic and biotic stress responses
    Trends Plant Sci. 2019; 24:413-430
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (48)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    A major structural and behavioral effect of all three treatments was production of large quantities of mucilage (Figure 6B). Many zygnematophycean algae secrete large amounts of extracellular polysaccharide mucilage through their cell walls, creating an extensive hydroscopic sheath. This material, also referred to as extracellular polymeric substance (EPS), has many functions that would provide an evolutionary advantage in semi-terrestrial habitats: anti-DE, a matrix for conjugation, a biofilm for communication with other microorganisms that might also facilitate HGT, and a propulsion mechanism where secretion from one pole of the cell allows directional gliding motility (Domozych and Domozych, 2008
    36.
    Domozych, D.S. ∙ Domozych, C.R.
    Desmids and biofilms of freshwater wetlands: development and microarchitecture
    Microb. Ecol. 2008; 55:81-93
    Crossref
    Scopus (21)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Mucilage production, which results in cell gliding behaviors (Videos S1 and S2), increased substantially within a few minutes of applying the HL, DE, and HLDE treatments (Figures 6C and 6D; Data S4B). Under DE and HLDE conditions, the EPS trails were more densely packed, leading to cell aggregation. This might be beneficial to an ephemeral alga whose short active growth period in the summer is defined by HL and drying conditions in shallow wetlands. The tight packing of EPS trails and cells would provide a means of enhancing water retention in a hydroscopic mass in desiccating environments.

    Consistent with the degree of the morphological and cytological changes, transcriptome profiling of P. margaritaceum revealed a greater response to DE than to the other two treatments (Figure 6E; Data S4C). Most of the DE-related differentially expressed genes (DEGs; 78% of the upregulated and 71% of the downregulated) were DE specific. HL had the least effect on transcript profiles, whereas combined treatment had an intermediate effect. Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis of the DEGs (Tables S2A–S2F; Data S4D) showed that the predominant categories of genes upregulated by all three treatments are related to carbohydrate metabolism. HL treatment caused induction of genes involved in central carbon metabolism, whereas photosynthesis-related pathways and associated chloroplast-related genes were significantly downregulated. This is consistent with suppression of photosynthesis to prevent cellular damage caused by HL-induced ROS, as occurs in land plants (Rossel et al., 2007
    116.
    Rossel, J.B. ∙ Wilson, P.B. ∙ Hussain, D. ...
    Systemic and intracellular responses to photooxidative stress in Arabidopsis
    Plant Cell. 2007; 19:4091-4110
    Crossref
    Scopus (165)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Complex networks of P. margaritaceum genes were identified as being regulated by DE or HL, including members of the GRAS family. This TF family had the greatest number of DEGs under DE (50 induced and 66 repressed), whereas none was differentially expressed under HL, indicating an ancestral role in abiotic stress responses. In addition, 20 of the 34 P. margaritaceum DREB TFs (Data S2D), which are only found in the Zygnematophyceae and land plants, were responsive to DE (5 upregulated and 15 downregulated), further suggesting a role in adaptations to increasingly terrestrial habitats.
    One of the most prominent transcriptome responses was a major upregulation by DE of genes annotated as being involved in polysaccharide metabolism and cell wall biosynthesis (Figure 6F; Table S2A). These include members of various GT classes, glycan synthases, and transglycosylases that function in the synthesis of diverse land plant cell wall polymers, including cellulose, xylan, and pectins. It might be expected that the transcriptome profiles reflect the biosynthesis of the mucilage that was induced in large quantities. An analysis of the polysaccharides in the mucilage secreted after HL or DE treatments (Tables S3A and S3B) revealed that they are quite distinct from those of the P. margaritaceum cell wall (Sørensen et al., 2011
    122.
    Sørensen, I. ∙ Pettolino, F.A. ∙ Bacic, A. ...
    The charophycean green algae provide insights into the early origins of plant cell walls
    Plant J. 2011; 68:201-211
    Crossref
    Scopus (137)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and showed compositional differences in response to different treatments. These gene sets might provide useful targets for future studies of the biosynthesis and function of the mucilage polymers.
    The transcriptome profiles also suggested that substantial cell wall remodeling occurred in response to DE. Large proportions of several of the families associated with cell wall loosening and degradation (48%, 77%, 68%, and 58% of GH28, PL, GH16, and expansin genes, respectively) were upregulated in DE-stressed cells. Congruent with upregulation of GH28 and PL pectinase genes, immunological analysis with a monoclonal antibody (JIM5) that recognizes the pectin polymer homogalacturonan (HG), showed that application of DE or HLDE stress caused major changes in the pectin architecture at the site of wall expansion at the isthmus zone (Figure S3A). This was confirmed by ultrastructural observations, which revealed that the HG lattice was significantly reduced, leaving the inner cellulosic wall layer (Figures S3B and S3C). This alteration most likely compromises the structural integrity of the wall, resulting in the unusual shapes of cells grown under these stress conditions. These results add to growing evidence that abiotic stresses such as DE cause remodeling of the cell wall in charophytes (Herburger and Holzinger, 2015; Holzinger and Pichrtová, 2016
    53.
    Herburger, K. ∙ Holzinger, A.

    Front. Plant Sci. 2016; 7:678
    Crossref
    Scopus (57)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and land plants (Tenhaken, 2015
    129.
    Tenhaken, R.
    Cell wall remodeling under abiotic stress
    Front. Plant Sci. 2015; 5:771
    Crossref
    Scopus (270)
    PubMed

    ). The major expansion of cell wall-modifying protein families in P. margaritaceum, together with their upregulation and turnover of their substrates in response to DE, highlights the importance of a structurally dynamic and robust primary cell wall under the changing osmotic conditions associated with habitats such as transient wetlands. The cell wall gene upregulation further suggests that these examples of wall modification are adaptive responses. These might be related to facilitating conjugation and mucilage secretion or specific changes in architecture that are biomechanically advantageous, but this remains to be determined. In this regard, the functions of specific cell wall genes can be addressed through transgenic approaches that have been developed for P. margaritaceum (Sørensen et al., 2014

    Sørensen, I. ∙ Fei, Z. ∙ Andreas, A. ...

    A previous study (de Vries et al., 2018
    30.
    de Vries, J. ∙ Curtis, B.A. ∙ Gould, S.B. ...
    Embryophyte stress signaling evolved in the algal progenitors of land plants
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2018; 115:E3471-E3480
    Crossref

    ) examined the effects of HL and cold stress on the transcriptomes of representatives of different streptophyte algal lineages. Direct comparisons of those results with outcomes of the HL and DE treatments reported here are limited by substantial differences in the treatment types, durations, and strengths. However, both sets of transcriptome data highlight the central role played by the plastid in diverse stress responses (Tables S2A, S2D, and S2E), and collectively they reveal distinct suites of genes that are regulated over hour-long versus multiple-day timescales. This lays the groundwork for future studies to elucidate the networks of short and longer-term adaptive responses to the multiple abiotic stresses inherent in terrestrialization.

    Discussion

    Approximately 600 mya, a common ancestor of the modern-day Zygnematophyceae and Embryophyta evolved a set of traits that enabled the process of terrestrialization. This led to the colonization of interstitial environments, such as ephemeral freshwater pools that experience periodic DE, and true terrestrial habitats. Subsequent evolutionary “tuning” gave rise to the great diversity of land plants that has ultimately transformed the natural history and biogeochemistry of the planet. A long-standing question in plant biology is the nature of the key evolutionary novelties and the adaptive traits that allowed the first colonizers to survive the challenges of life on land; notably DE, UV radiation, and the need for biomechanical support. Answers lie in comparative studies of early-diverging land plant lineages and members of their sister group, the zygnematophycean algae.
    The P. margaritaceum genome sequence has the hallmarks of a dynamic source of genetic innovation, with abundant TEs and the emergence or major expansion of gene families and regulatory systems that are associated with terrestrialization. These include a large compendium of regulatory TF families and components of phytohormone signaling networks that govern stress-induced changes in cell morphology and physiology. We also identified UV-absorbing flavonoid compounds and a range of land plant-like cellular responses to light and DE. The genome provides evidence of extensive machinery for synthesis, secretion, and remodeling of the polysaccharide cell wall, much of which originated prior to the ancestral land plant. This is exemplified by the substantially expanded repertoire of genes involved in the metabolism of pectins. These apparently ancient macromolecules contribute to cell expansion and cell differentiation as well as to the formation of the middle lamella that mediates intercellular adhesion, allowing tissue and organ formation in embryophytes (Zamil and Geitmann, 2017; Cosgrove, 2014
    25.
    Cosgrove, D.J.
    Re-constructing our models of cellulose and primary cell wall assembly
    Curr. Opin. Plant Biol. 2014; 22:122-131
    Crossref
    Scopus (203)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    145.
    Zamil, M.S. ∙ Geitmann, A.
    The middle lamella-more than a glue
    Phys. Biol. 2017; 14:015004
    Crossref
    Scopus (21)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Additionally, although most terrestrial plant life requires more extensive deposition of hydrophobic biopolymers to reinforce the walls of specialized cells, the origins of their building blocks can increasingly be traced back to aquatic ancestors.
    It is important to note that all zygnematophycean taxa are believed to be derived from multicellular ancestors (Delwiche and Cooper, 2015
    33.
    Delwiche, C.F. ∙ Cooper, E.D.
    The evolutionary origin of a terrestrial flora
    Curr. Biol. 2015; 25:R899-R910
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), whereas the lineage today is represented by a diverse assemblage of both multicellular (i.e., filamentous forms) and unicellular (e.g., the desmids) taxa. The unicellular morphology of P. margaritaceum represents a major evolutionary secondary reduction that affords significant advantages to life in semi-aquatic or subaerial habitats. Small size, rapid cell division, simple conjugation-based sexual reproduction, and the ability to withstand DE-based stress, together with the synthetic machinery to secrete water-retaining mucilage, provide a more efficient means to survive in shallow wetlands than the multicellular body plans and complex reproductive strategies of other late-divergent charophytes.
    It has been proposed that the common ancestor of land plants and the Zygnematophyceae might have acquired additional genetic capacity through HGT from soil bacteria (Cheng et al., 2019
    21.
    Cheng, S. ∙ Xian, W. ∙ Fu, Y. ...
    Genomes of subaerial Zygnematophyceae provide insights into land plant evolution
    Cell. 2019; 179:1057-1067.e14
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (58)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Other mechanisms of major gene expansion are apparent in different lineages of the Zygnematophyceae, such as whole-genome triplication in S. muscicola (Cheng et al., 2019
    21.
    Cheng, S. ∙ Xian, W. ∙ Fu, Y. ...
    Genomes of subaerial Zygnematophyceae provide insights into land plant evolution
    Cell. 2019; 179:1057-1067.e14
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (58)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and massive segmental duplication in P. margaritaceum. Importantly, the three zygnematophycean species compared here diverged deep within the lineage more than 500 mya, and since then, secondary losses and gains of traits have occurred as they adapted to their unique subaerial and/or semi-terrestrial habitats. Thus, although the genetic framework and structural and physiological features that set in motion one of the great transitions of life on Earth are coming into focus, sequencing of additional genomes will be necessary to elucidate the variation within the Zygnematophyceae and the nature of their last common ancestor with embryophytes.

    Data and Code Availability

    The genome sequence of P. margaritaceum has been deposited at DDBJ/ENA/GenBank under the accession SZWC00000000. The version described in this paper is version SZWC01000000.     Experimental Model and Subject Details

    Penium margaritaceum Brébisson (Skidmore isolate #8 of the Skidmore College Culture Collection - Texas) was isolated from shallow wetland, Saratoga Springs, NY, 12866, USA (Latitude 43.34N, Longitude 73.61W) and maintained in sterile 100 mL liquid cultures of Woods Hole (WH) medium (Nichols, 1973
    95.
    Nichols, H.W.
    Growth media-freshwater
    Stein, J.R. (Editor)
    Handbook of phycological methods: culture methods and growth measurements
    Cambridge University Press, New York, 1973; 39-78
    Google Scholar
    ) supplemented with soil extract WHS obtained from Carolina Biological (North Carolina, USA), pH 7.2 at 18 ± 2°C in a photoperiod of 16 h light/8 h dark with 74 μmol photons m−2 s−1 Photosynthetic Photon Flux of cool white fluorescent light. Subcultures were made every 10 days and 10- to 14-day-old cultures were used for all experiments.

    Method Details

    Stress treatments

    For the control and high light (HL) treatments, cultures were maintained in 50 mL aliquots of WHS in sterile 150 × 15 mm plastic Petri dishes. Cultures (5 mL; 2,000 cells mL−1) were added to each dish, which was then sealed with surgical tape and placed under HL (150 μmol photons m−2 s−1, 18 ± 2°C), or control (74 μmol photons m−2 s−1, 18 ± 2°C) conditions. For the desiccation (DE) treatment, 150 × 15 mm plastic Petri dishes were filled with 50 mL of WHS containing 2% agarose (Sigma, USA) and allowed to cool. Two sterile 80-mm diameter cellulose sheets (AA Packaging, USA) were added to each plate and 1 mL of concentrated cell culture (~5,000 cells mL−1) was spread onto the sheets. The plates were then sealed and placed under control conditions or HL to produce high light plus desiccation (HLDE) conditions. Cells from the three treatments or the control were collected after 14 days by centrifugation at 1,500 × g for 1 min, the pellets washed three times by resuspension in sterile WHS, shaking and centrifugation, and then frozen in liquid nitrogen. For DE experiments, the cells were scraped off the cellulose sheets and frozen in liquid nitrogen. Three biological replicates were performed for each treatment or control.

    Cell labeling and imaging

    Cells grown in liquid culture under control or stress conditions were washed three times with WHS, centrifuged (400 × g for 1 min) and the cell pellet was gently resuspended in WHS (1,000 cells mL−1 ± 50). Samples (200 μL) were placed in the center of a single-welled polytetrafluoroethylene printed slide (Electron Microscopy Sciences, Hatfield, PA, USA) and mixed with 50 μL of a 100 μg/mL solution of Fluoresbrite Plain YG 0.5 μm Microspheres, or with 0.5 μm Polybead Polystyrene Microspheres (Polysciences, Warrington, PA, USA). The mixed suspensions were covered with a 22 × 22 mm glass coverslip and imaged with either light microscopy (LM; Olympus BX-60 or IX-83 equipped with both wide field fluorescence and differential interference contrast optics), or confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM; Olympus Fluoview 1200 CLSM). Single images or Free Run time lapse video clips were acquired with Olympus DP-73 cameras. For some experiments, the slides were placed in a moisture chamber comprising a glass Petri dish with a layer of wet filter paper. The chambers were placed under the control and HL conditions for various periods of time and then viewed with LM or CLSM. To image the mucilage in DE cultures, cell aggregates were removed from the surface of desiccation cultures, placed on the slides as above and a drop of 0.5 mg/mL Fluoresbrite bead solution was placed on the cell aggregate. The coverslip was then added and the slide viewed with LM or CLSM. To visualize starch, cell pellets were resuspended in growth medium and stained for 5 min with 1% v/v iodine then washed before imaging. Immunolabeling of cell wall pectin followed the protocol of Rydahl et al. (2015)

    ) and for Iso-Seq was extracted using the RNeasy Mini kit (QIAGEN, USA). The quality of RNA was checked using an Agilent BioAnalyzer (Agilent, USA). For genomic DNA extraction, nuclei were isolated from the cell pellets as described in Raimundo et al. (2018)
    110.
    Raimundo, S.C. ∙ Sørensen, I. ∙ Tinaz, B. ...
    Isolation and manipulation of protoplasts from the unicellular green alga Penium margaritaceum

    Crossref
    Scopus (3)
    Google Scholar
     as this yielded far better-quality preparations. DNA quality was checked using a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) and an Agilent BioAnalyzer (Agilent, USA).
    Five paired-end genomic libraries were constructed, of which three were prepared with the Illumina TruSeq DNA PCR-Free Prep kit, one with the Illumina Genomic DNA Sample Prep kit and one with the Kapa Hyper kit (Kapa Biosystem, USA). Three mate-pair libraries were constructed using the Illumina Nextera Mate Pair Library Prep kit with insert sizes ranging between 2-4 kb, 5-7 kb and 8-10 kb, respectively. All libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500 system in paired-end mode.
    Strand-specific RNA-Seq libraries were constructed for stressed and control samples as previously described (Zhong et al., 2011
    150.
    Zhong, S. ∙ Joung, J.-G. ∙ Zheng, Y. ...
    High-throughput illumina strand-specific RNA sequencing library preparation

    Scopus (264)

    ) and sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2500 system in paired-end mode. The Iso-Seq library was constructed following the standard SMRT bell construction protocol (Pacific Biosciences, USA) and sequenced using two SMRT cells on the PacBio Sequel platform (v2.0 chemistry).

    Transcriptome assembly

    Long reads produced by the PacBio Sequel platform were processed using modules in the SMRTLink package (v5.1; PacBio), to generate full-length refined consensus isoforms. Circular consensus sequences (CCS) were obtained using the ‘ccs’ module with parameters “–minPredictedAccuracy=0.75, MinFullPasses =0 and–minLength=100.” CCS containing poly(A) signal, 5′ and 3′ adapters were then identified, and the adapters and poly(A) sequences were trimmed to create full-length non-chimeric (FLNC) reads. The retained FLNC reads were iteratively classified into clusters to build the consensus sequences, which were then polished by Quiver (Chin et al., 2013
    22.
    Chin, C.-S. ∙ Alexander, D.H. ∙ Marks, P. ...
    Nonhybrid, finished microbial genome assemblies from long-read SMRT sequencing data
    Nat. Methods. 2013; 10:563-569
    Crossref
    Scopus (2263)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with the minimum accuracy rate set to 0.99. Base errors in the polished isoforms were further corrected by Illumina RNA-Seq reads using LoRDEC v0.8 (Salmela and Rivals, 2014
    118.
    Salmela, L. ∙ Rivals, E.
    LoRDEC: accurate and efficient long read error correction
    Bioinformatics. 2014; 30:3506-3514
    Crossref
    Scopus (210)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with kmer length set to 19. The LoRDEC-corrected isoforms were used to reconstruct the coding regions of the P. margaritaceum genome using Cogent v3.5 (https://github.com/Magdoll/Cogent). To build gene clusters, all the isoforms were aligned to the P. margaritaceum coding genome (the collection of coding sequences generated by Cogent) by minimap2 with parameters “-ax splice -uf” (Li, 2018
    71.
    Li, H.
    Minimap2: pairwise alignment for nucleotide sequences
    Bioinformatics. 2018; 34:3094-3100
    Crossref
    Scopus (753)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), and the resulting alignments were then processed by cDNA_Cupcake (https://github.com/Magdoll/cDNA_Cupcake) to collapse isoforms.
    Illumina RNA-Seq reads were processed with Trimmomatic v0.32 (Bolger et al., 2014
    11.
    Bolger, A.M. ∙ Lohse, M. ∙ Usadel, B.
    Trimmomatic: a flexible trimmer for Illumina sequence data
    Bioinformatics. 2014; 30:2114-2120
    Crossref
    Scopus (14636)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to remove adaptor and low-quality sequences. Reads aligned to the ribosomal RNA database (Quast et al., 2013
    109.
    Quast, C. ∙ Pruesse, E. ∙ Yilmaz, P. ...
    The SILVA ribosomal RNA gene database project: improved data processing and web-based tools
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2013; 41:D590-D596

    50.

    148.
    Zheng, Y. ∙ Zhao, L. ∙ Gao, J. ...
    iAssembler: a package for de novo assembly of Roche-454/Sanger transcriptome sequences
    BMC Bioinformatics. 2011; 12:453

    Genome assembly

    Genomic paired-end reads were processed to remove adaptors and low-quality bases using Trimmomatic v0.32 (Bolger et al., 2014
    11.
    Bolger, A.M. ∙ Lohse, M. ∙ Usadel, B.

    ) with parameters “TruSeq3-PE-2.fa:2:30:10:1:TRUE SLIDINGWINDOW:4:20 LEADING:3 TRAILING:3 MINLEN:40.” Mate-pair reads were cleaned with the ShortRead package (Morgan et al., 2009
    89.
    Morgan, M. ∙ Anders, S. ∙ Lawrence, M. ...
    ShortRead: a bioconductor package for input, quality assessment and exploration of high-throughput sequence data
    Bioinformatics. 2009; 25:2607-2608
    Crossref
    Scopus (261)
    PubMed

    ) to remove the junction adaptor sequences and the trailing bases.
    To assemble the genome, we first searched for optimal k-mer size. Since the P. margaritaceum genome is highly repetitive, large k-mer size can help resolve repetitive regions but with a trade-off of increasing the number of unique k-mers, which requires more computational resources. For P. margaritaceum genome assembly, memory efficiency was a major bottleneck for most of the popular assemblers we tried, including MaSuRCA (Zimin et al., 2013
    152.
    Zimin, A.V. ∙ Marçais, G. ∙ Puiu, D. ...

    Crossref
    Scopus (8111)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), ALLPATHS-LG (Gnerre et al., 2011
    48.
    Gnerre, S. ∙ Maccallum, I. ∙ Przybylski, D. ...

    Nadalin, F. ∙ Vezzi, F. ∙ Policriti, A.

    Additional steps were taken to improve the contiguity and gene space of the assembly. First, the genome was also assembled successfully by MEGAHIT v1.1.1-2-g02102e1 (Li et al., 2015
    74.
    Li, D. ∙ Liu, C.M. ∙ Luo, R. ...
    MEGAHIT: an ultra-fast single-node solution for large and complex metagenomics assembly via succinct de Bruijn graph
    Bioinformatics. 2015; 31:1674-1676
    Crossref
    Scopus (852)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) using discrete k-mer sizes (121, 139, 159, 179, 199, 219, 239 and 249). Although the overall quality of the MEGAHIT assembly (contig N50: 498bp; scaffold N50: 696 bp) was not better, some long contigs were used for further scaffolding or gap filling of the SOAPdenovo2 assembly. MEGAHIT contigs > 2 kb were used in a BLAST search against the SOAPdenovo2 assembly (identity > 99%; minimal HSP length > 100 bp). Gapped scaffolds uniquely spanned by MEGAHIT sequences were filled, or replaced if they were contained by MEGAHIT sequences. When one MEGAHIT contig was aligned to two SOAPdenovo2 scaffolds, and the two alignments in the MEGAHIT contig did not overlap, the SOAPdenovo2 scaffolds were joined with gaps (100 Ns) if the anchors were located on each contig at the termini and were ≥ 100 nucleotides. Second, the genome assembly was further improved with assistance of PacBio full-length transcripts and Illumina de novo assembled transcripts. The transcripts were aligned to the genome assembly using GMAP v2017-10-12 (Wu and Watanabe 2005
    140.
    Wu, T.D. ∙ Watanabe, C.K.
    GMAP: a genomic mapping and alignment program for mRNA and EST sequences
    Bioinformatics. 2005; 21:1859-1875
    Crossref
    Scopus (1051)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with parameters “–min-identity=0.95–max-intronlength-middle 50000 -L 100000.” If a transcript was uniquely mapped to two scaffolds and the alignments met the following criteria, the two scaffolds were joined with gaps (100 Ns): a) individual alignment length > 100 bp; b) total alignments should cover > 80% of the transcript; and c) alignments on the scaffolds should be located within 5 kb of the closest terminus. Consequently, 3,971 scaffolds (∼111 Mb) were successfully connected. Lastly, transcripts not covered by the SOAPdenovo2 assembly but with solid homologs in the NCBI protein database were mapped to the MEGAHIT assembly, and the aligned MEGAHIT contigs, if not redundant, were added to the SOAPdenovo2 assembly.

The assembly was further checked for redundancy as described above. Scaffolds with BLASTn hits (E-value < 1e-5) from non-eukaryotic organisms were manually examined to exclude contamination.

    Repeat annotation

    Long terminal repeat (LTR) retrotransposons were identified from the P. margaritaceum genome assembly using LTRharvest v1.5.9 (Ellinghaus et al., 2008
    41.
    Ellinghaus, D. ∙ Kurtz, S. ∙ Willhoeft, U.
    LTRharvest, an efficient and flexible software for de novo detection of LTR retrotransposons
    BMC Bioinformatics. 2008; 9:18
    Crossref
    Scopus (323)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with parameters ‘-minlenltr 100 -maxlenltr 6000 -mindistltr 1500 -maxdistltr 25000 -mintsd 5 -maxtsd 5 -motif tgca -vic 10’) and LTRdigest (Steinbiss et al., 2009
    126.
    Steinbiss, S. ∙ Willhoeft, U. ∙ Gremme, G. ...
    Fine-grained annotation and classification of de novo predicted LTR retrotransposons
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2009; 37:7002-7013
    Crossref
    Scopus (117)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), and miniature inverted transposable elements (MITEs) were identified using MITE-Hunter v11-2011 (Han and Wessler, 2010
    52.
    Han, Y. ∙ Wessler, S.R.
    MITE-Hunter: a program for discovering miniature inverted-repeat transposable elements from genomic sequences
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2010; 38:e199
    Crossref
    Scopus (188)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with parameter ‘-n 30’. The identified LTRs and MITEs were used to mask the P. margaritaceum genome using RepeatMasker (v4.0.7; http://www.repeatmasker.org), and the unmasked genomic sequences were analyzed by RepeatModeler (v1.0.11; http://www.repeatmasker.org/RepeatModeler.html) to identify novel transposable elements (TEs). All identified repeat sequences were searched against the Swiss-Prot database (https://www.uniprot.org:443/) using BLASTx with an E-value cutoff of 1e-10, and repeats matching non-TE proteins in the database were excluded. To annotate the repeats, we used a modified approach similar to that implemented in the RepeatClassifier module of RepeatModeler. First, we ran the RepeatClassifier on all identified repeats to get a summary statistic of BLASTx matches against a TE protein dataset provided by RepeatMasker. Repeats were categorized based on the classification of best hits (E-value < 1e-3 and alignment length > 150 nucleotides or 50 residues). The unclassified repeats were scanned by RepeatMasker with all eukaryotic TEs from the Repbase database (Bao et al., 2015
    6.
    Bao, W. ∙ Kojima, K.K. ∙ Kohany, O.
    Repbase Update, a database of repetitive elements in eukaryotic genomes
    Mob. DNA. 2015; 6:11
    Crossref
    Scopus (684)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (version 20170127). Best hits, with alignments > 200 nucleotides, were kept for TE family assignment. Simple repeat annotation was performed with an independent run of the TRF program v 4.09 with parameters: “2 7 7 80 10 50 2000 -h -f -d -m 1 -l 10” (Benson, 1999
    9.
    Benson, G.
    Tandem repeats finder: a program to analyze DNA sequences
    Nucleic Acids Res. 1999; 27:573-580
    Crossref
    Scopus (3910)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Ossowski, S. ∙ Schneeberger, K. ∙ Lucas-Lledó, J.I. ...

The Trinity assemblies, combined with 29,220 expressed sequence tags (ESTs) from the NCBI nucleotide database, were fed to the MAKER-P pipeline as transcript evidence.
    The final MAKER-P gene models were compared to the Pfam database to exclude those containing TE-related domains. Genes with expression value RPKM (reads per kilobase of exon model per million mapped reads) ≥ 1 in combined RNA-Seq data or having at least one valid hit in the nr, Pfam, InterPro, or PANTHER databases were classified as high-confidence genes, whereas the rest of the predicted genes were grouped into a low-confidence gene set.

    Development of the master gene set

    To further improve gene completeness, a master gene set was created by incorporating PacBio full-length transcripts and Trinity assembled transcripts into the high-confidence (HC) gene set. Transcript sequences were subjected to SeqClean (https://sourceforge.net/projects/seqclean) for polyA tail trimming and rRNA sequence removal. Coding regions of the transcripts were identified by TransDecoder, and only those with coding sequences > 90 nucleotides were kept. CD-HIT (Fu et al., 2012
    46.
    Fu, L. ∙ Niu, B. ∙ Zhu, Z. ...
    CD-HIT: accelerated for clustering the next-generation sequencing data
    Bioinformatics. 2012; 28:3150-3152
    Crossref
    Scopus (2228)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used to cluster the coding sequences to remove redundancies. Coding sequences of Trinity assembled transcripts were removed if they shared > 90% identity with Iso-Seq isoforms. The remaining coding sequences were mapped to the P. margaritaceum genome using GMAP (Wu and Watanabe 2005
    140.
    Wu, T.D. ∙ Watanabe, C.K.
    GMAP: a genomic mapping and alignment program for mRNA and EST sequences
    Bioinformatics. 2005; 21:1859-1875
    Crossref
    Scopus (1051)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with parameters “-n 0 -z sense force.” According to the alignments, HC genes predicted from the P. margaritaceum genome were replaced with corresponding coding transcripts if all the following criteria were met: a) alignment between the transcript and the HC gene covered > 80% of the HC coding region; b) the length of coding sequence of the transcript was at least 1.1 times of that of the HC gene; c) length of the transcript coding sequence should not exceed 1.5 times of the average length of the top 10 protein homologs in the GenBank non-redundant (nr) database (to avoid chimeric transcripts); and d) the transcript in question contained the longest coding sequence in the locus.
    Some transcripts did not align to the genome or the alignments were located in intergenic regions. To identify likely protein-coding genes from these transcripts, we assessed their coding potential using CPC (Kong et al., 2007
    66.
    Kong, L. ∙ Zhang, Y. ∙ Ye, Z.-Q. ...
    CPC: assess the protein-coding potential of transcripts using sequence features and support vector machine
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2007; 35:W345-9
    Crossref
    Scopus (1080)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and discarded those annotated as non-coding transcripts. We also excluded the remaining transcripts without any protein homologs in Viridiplantae species, and those whose predicted protein sequences were considered to be too long (≥1.5 times the average length of their homologs) or too short (≤0.5 times the average length of their homologs). In addition, transcripts encoding TE-related Pfam domains were removed. For the remaining transcripts, we only included the longest transcript for each locus into the master gene set.
    To annotate genes in the master list, their protein sequences were compared to the GenBank nr database, the A. thaliana proteome and the UniProt database using BLASTp with an E-value cutoff of 1e-5. The protein sequences were also compared to the InterPro database using InterProScan v5.29-68.0 (Jones et al., 2014
    58.
    Jones, P. ∙ Binns, D. ∙ Chang, H.-Y. ...
    InterProScan 5: genome-scale protein function classification
    Bioinformatics. 2014; 30:1236-1240
    Crossref
    Scopus (2286)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Gene ontology (GO) annotations were obtained using Blast2GO v5.2.4 (Götz et al., 2008
    49.
    Götz, S. ∙ García-Gómez, J.M. ∙ Terol, J. ...
    High-throughput functional annotation and data mining with the Blast2GO suite
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2008; 36:3420-3435
    Crossref
    Scopus (2145)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) based on the BLASTp results from the GenBank nr database and output from the InterProScan. Functional descriptions were integrated and assigned to the genes using AHRD (v3.3.3; https://github.com/groupschoof/AHRD). Enzyme Commission (EC) information was acquired from the Blast2GO analysis. Pathway analysis was performed using the online annotation server BlastKOALA (Kanehisa et al., 2016
    60.
    Kanehisa, M. ∙ Sato, Y. ∙ Morishima, K.
    BlastKOALA and GhostKOALA: KEGG tools for functional characterization of genome and metagenome sequences

    ) with parameters “E-value < 1e-5; alignment coverage > 40%; inflation value 1.5.” To infer the species phylogeny, we retrieved sequences from low-copy orthologous groups, defined as those with ≤ 3 gene copies in each species and at most two species with multi-copy genes, or missing genes.     61.
    Katoh, K. ∙ Standley, D.M.

    Mol. Biol. Evol. 2013; 30:772-780

    ) and gaps in the alignment were trimmed using trimAl (Capella-Gutiérrez et al., 2009

    Scopus (2548)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with parameter “-automated1.” A Maximum likelihood phylogeny was inferred by IQ-TREE (Nguyen et al., 2015
    94.
    Nguyen, L.-T. ∙ Schmidt, H.A. ∙ von Haeseler, A. ...
    IQ-TREE: a fast and effective stochastic algorithm for estimating maximum-likelihood phylogenies
    Mol. Biol. Evol. 2015; 32:268-274
    Crossref
    Scopus (4058)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (v1.6.7) with concatenated alignments and the best-fitting model LG+F+I+G4, and 1,000 bootstrap replicates. Molecular dating was carried out by MCMCTree in the PAML package version 4.9h (Yang, 2007
    141.
    Yang, Z.
    PAML 4: phylogenetic analysis by maximum likelihood
    Mol. Biol. Evol. 2007; 24:1586-1591
    Crossref
    Scopus (6299)

    ). The divergence time of Angiospermae (246.6-195.4 Mya), Tracheophyta (450.8-430.4 Mya), Embryophyta (515.5-469.0 Mya), Streptophyta (875.4-637.4 Mya) and Viridiplantae (968.0-676.7 Mya) were used as calibration points according to Morris et al. (2018)
    90.
    Morris, J.L. ∙ Puttick, M.N. ∙ Clark, J.W. ...
    The timescale of early land plant evolution

    Crossref
    Scopus (195)
    PubMed

    . We repeated molecular dating by applying ten different combinations of any two of the calibration points and derived the mean and standard error of divergence time at each node from the replicates (Table S1E). For gene family evolution analysis, we used 11,904 orthologous groups with genes present in at least two algal species and two land plants. Modeling of gene family size was performed by CAFE (De Bie et al., 2006
    27.
    De Bie, T. ∙ Cristianini, N. ∙ Demuth, J.P. ...
    CAFE: a computational tool for the study of gene family evolution
    Bioinformatics. 2006; 22:1269-1271
    Crossref
    Scopus (416)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) (v4.2) and the gene birth and death rate (λ) was estimated with orthologous groups that were conserved in at least 17 (out of 18) species. Orthologous groups with family-wide p < 0.05 were defined as rapidly evolving gene families whereas, the Viterbi p (< 0.05) was used to identify branches with gene families significantly expanded or contracted compared with their last common ancestor.

    Whole genome duplication (WGD)

    WGD can be inferred from the Ks (synonymous substitution rate) values of paralogous genes (Vanneste et al., 2013
    132.
    Vanneste, K. ∙ Van de Peer, Y. ∙ Maere, S.
    Inference of genome duplications from age distributions revisited
    Mol. Biol. Evol. 2013; 30:177-190
    Crossref
    Scopus (76)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To explore possible WGD in P. margaritaceum, we calculated Ks for each pair of P. margaritaceum genes within the same orthologous groups. Ks values > 2 were excluded from the analysis due to saturation. We fitted the Ks values with a Gaussian mixture model (GMM) implemented in mclust R package (Scrucca et al., 2016
    119.
    Scrucca, L. ∙ Fop, M. ∙ Murphy, T.B. ...
    mclust 5: Clustering, classification and density estimation using Gaussian finite mixture models
    R J. 2016; 8:289-317
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) to identify possible WGD signatures. GMM is a probabilistic model that assumes all the data points are generated from a mixture of a number of Gaussian distributions with unknown components. However, model selection on the optimal number of GMM components is prone to overfitting, so we performed significant zero crossing (SiZer) and significant convexity (SiCon) analysis implemented in the R package (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/feature/index.html) to check the authenticity of the components at a significance level of 0.05.

    Gene family identification

    The transcription factors, transcriptional regulators and protein kinases in P. margaritaceum and other selected species were identified and classified based on the rules of the iTAK pipeline v1.7 (Zheng et al., 2016
    149.
    Zheng, Y. ∙ Jiao, C. ∙ Sun, H. ...
    iTAK: a program for genome-wide prediction and classification of plant transcription factors, transcriptional regulators, and protein kinases
    Mol. Plant. 2016; 9:1667-1670
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (177)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).
    To identify homologous genes, protein sequences from P. margaritaceum and other selected species were searched against A. thaliana protein database using BLASTp (E-value ≤ 1e-5 and coverage of A. thaliana genes ≥ 30%), and genes with the best hit to the targeted A. thaliana genes or their potential paralogs, which were defined by BLASTp under the criteria of E-value ≤ 1e-5 and reciprocal coverage ≥ 35%, were preserved as candidate homologous genes. For some gene families, the homologs were identified based on the specific protein domains that were searched by HMMER3 (Mistry et al., 2013
    88.
    Mistry, J. ∙ Finn, R.D. ∙ Eddy, S.R. ...
    Challenges in homology search: HMMER3 and convergent evolution of coiled-coil regions
    Nucleic Acids Res. 2013; 41:e121
    Crossref
    Scopus (373)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with parameter “–cut-ga,” or classified based on the iTAK results (http://itak.feilab.net/; specified in Table S1J). For hormone pathway genes, protein sequences of all the A. thaliana genes as well as the homolog candidates in other species were aligned using MAFFT with the linsi strategy (Katoh and Standley, 2013
    61.
    Katoh, K. ∙ Standley, D.M.
    MAFFT multiple sequence alignment software version 7: improvements in performance and usability
    Mol. Biol. Evol. 2013; 30:772-780
    Crossref
    Scopus (12620)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and the maximum likelihood phylogeny for each family was constructed by IQ-TREE (Nguyen et al., 2015
    94.
    Nguyen, L.-T. ∙ Schmidt, H.A. ∙ von Haeseler, A. ...
    IQ-TREE: a fast and effective stochastic algorithm for estimating maximum-likelihood phylogenies
    Mol. Biol. Evol. 2015; 32:268-274
    Crossref
    Scopus (4058)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with automatic model selection and 1,000 bootstrap replicates. The final homologs were inferred from the built phylogeny of individual gene families.

    Carbohydrate-active enzyme (CAZy) family

    Zhang, H. ∙ Yohe, T. ∙ Huang, L. ...

    ), and unless indicated the default thresholds (E-value < 1e-15 and coverage > 35%) were used to delineate each gene family.

    GH16 sequence analysis

    BLASTp was used to search the proteomes of P. margaritaceum, M. endlicherianum, S. muscicola, C. braunii, K. nitens, C. atmophyticus and M. viride with sequences from a GH16 sequence database (http://bioinfo.bti.cornell.edu/lab/GH16.fasta.gz) as queries, including laminarinases, agarases, porphyranases, carrageenases, MLGases, chitin transglycosylases, EG16s and XTHs. The resulting sequences were analyzed manually and candidates were analyzed using SignalP (http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/SignalP/) and TargetP (http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/TargetP/), and compared to the NCBI conserved domain database (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/wrpsb.cgi). The identified GH16s were also aligned with other GH16 sequences and the presence of conserved EG16 and XTH motifs was noted. For the GH16 phylogeny, several representatives of each GH16 group were aligned with all non-fragment P. margaritaceum sequences (n = 41), M. endlicherianum (n = 6), S. muscicola (n = 17), C. braunii (n = 6), K. nitens (n = 12), C. atmophyticus (n = 5) and M. viride (n = 1) sequences and GH7 cellulases (as the outgroup), then trimmed. To generate the tree, RAxML-HPC2 (Stamatakis 2014
    124.
    Stamatakis, A.
    RAxML version 8: a tool for phylogenetic analysis and post-analysis of large phylogenies
    Bioinformatics. 2014; 30:1312-1313
    Crossref
    Scopus (12231)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) on XSEDE was used on the CIPRES portal (http://www.phylo.org), with the JTT amino acid substitution model, which ran for 360 rapid bootstraps.

    Protein structure modeling

    The protein structure of Arabidopsis ARF1 (PDB accession number 4LDX) was used as the template for structure modeling of P. margaritaceum ARF proteins using SWISS-MODEL (Waterhouse et al., 2018

    Waterhouse, A. ∙ Bertoni, M. ∙ Bienert, S. ...

    ) with default parameters. The target and template sequences were aligned using MAFFT with the linsi strategy and the protein structure was visualized using Chimera (version 1.13.1) (Pettersen et al., 2004
    105.
    Pettersen, E.F. ∙ Goddard, T.D. ∙ Huang, C.C. ...
    UCSF Chimera--a visualization system for exploratory research and analysis
    J. Comput. Chem. 2004; 25:1605-1612
    Crossref
    Scopus (19985)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Differential gene expression analysis

    Cleaned RNA-Seq reads were used to quantify expression of P. margaritaceum master genes in each sample using Salmon v0.9.1 (quasi mode; -k 31) (Patro et al., 2017
    103.
    Patro, R. ∙ Duggal, G. ∙ Love, M.I. ...
    Salmon provides fast and bias-aware quantification of transcript expression
    Nat. Methods. 2017; 14:417-419
    Crossref
    Scopus (1349)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Raw counts were normalized to fragments per kilobase of exon per million mapped fragments (FPKM). Differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between treated and control samples were identified using the DESeq2 package (Love et al., 2014
    79.
    Love, M.I. ∙ Huber, W. ∙ Anders, S.
    Moderated estimation of fold change and dispersion for RNA-seq data with DESeq2
    Genome Biol. 2014; 15:550
    Crossref
    Scopus (14606)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Genes with false discovery rate (FDR) < 0.01 and fold-change > 2 were considered to be DEGs. GO enrichment analysis of the DEGs was performed using BiNGO (Maere et al., 2005
    83.
    Maere, S. ∙ Heymans, K. ∙ Kuiper, M.
    BiNGO: a Cytoscape plugin to assess overrepresentation of gene ontology categories in biological networks
    Bioinformatics. 2005; 21:3448-3449
    Crossref
    Scopus (2591)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ).

    Flavonoid and mucilage analysis

    Flavonoids were extracted from P. margaritaceum cell culture pellets according to Ye et al. (2015)
    142.
    Ye, J. ∙ Hu, T. ∙ Yang, C. ...
    Transcriptome profiling of tomato fruit development reveals transcription factors associated with ascorbic acid, carotenoid and flavonoid biosynthesis
    PLoS ONE. 2015; 10:e0130885
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    . Freeze-dried samples were homogenized with a TissueLyser II (QIAGEN), extracted overnight at 4°C with 80% methanol then centrifuged at 13,000 × g for 10 min. The supernatant was retained and the pellet re-extracted with 80% methanol for 1 h and centrifuged as before. The supernatants were pooled and dried using a speed-vac then reconstituted in 120 μL of solvent (40 μL MeOH + 80 μL H2O) prior to analysis by liquid chromatography mass spectrometry using a Thermo Scientific Vanquish UHPLC system (mobile phase A, water with 0.1% formic acid; mobile phase B, methanol with 0.1% formic acid), with a Thermo Scientific Hypersil Gold column (2.1 × 150mm, 1.9μm) operating at 45°C with a flow rate of 200 μL min−1. Separation of compounds was carried out with gradient elution profile: 0 min, A:B 99.5:0.5; 1 min, A:B 90:10; 10 min, A:B 70:30, 18 min, A:B 50:50, 22 min, A:B 1:99; total 30 min. The injection volume was 2 μL.
    MS and MSn data were collected with a Thermo Scientific Orbitrap ID-X Tribrid mass spectrometer. Flavonoids were identified using the automated iterative precursor exclusion method of the Acquire X workflow (four iterative runs of the pooled sample). The MS2 (30 K FWHM at m/z 200) spectra were collected for precursor ions detected in the survey MS scan within a 1.2 s cycle time. Higher order MSn (3–4) (30 K FWHM at m/z 200) spectra were collected only when the instrument detected the sugar neutral loss based on MS2 and/or MS3 data. Flavonoids were identified and annotated by searching MSn tree raw data files against mzCloud spectra library using Mass Frontier 8.0. The identified list (full or partial MSn spectral tree data matching MSn spectra of flavonoid references in the mzCloud library) plus an existing database with 6,549 flavonoid structures were used for database search in Compound Discoverer 3.1 software (Thermo Scientific). The putative identified flavonoids by were further analyzed for structure annotation by the FISh ranking tool (Mass Frontier 8.0).
    Mucilage (EPS) was isolated from cultures as described in Domozych et al. (2005)
    37.
    Domozych, D.S. ∙ Kort, S. ∙ Benton, S. ...
    The extracellular polymeric substance of the green alga Penium margaritaceum and its role in biofilm formation
    Biofilms. 2005; 2:129-144
    Crossref
    Scopus (40)
    Google Scholar
     and freeze-dried. Polysaccharide composition and linkage analyses were performed by the carbohydrate analytical service of the Complex Carbohydrate Research Center, University of Georgia (https://www.ccrc.uga.edu/services).

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    Quantification approaches and statistical analyses of the genome sequencing, quality assessment of the assembly and the predicated genes, gene family evolution, phylogeny, as well as the gene expression under different stresses can be found in the relevant sections of the Method Details.

    Cookie Preference Center

    We use cookies which are necessary to make our site work. We may also use additional cookies to analyse, improve and personalise our content and your digital experience. For more information, see our Cookie Policy and the list of Google Ad-Tech Vendors.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
